req_list.name: Introductory Courses
req_list.explanation: Some of the above can be satisfied by equivalent courses. For example, students with an interest in structures may take CEE 205 Mechanics of Solids in place of MAE 223; and students with an interest in engineering physics may take PHY 205 Classical Mechanics or PHY 207 Mechanics and Waves in place of MAE 206.

req_list.name: Departmental Concentration
req_list.explanation:
A minimum of eight upper level Departmental courses are required. This includes Senior Independent Work. 

None of the Department requirements can be taken on a pass/fail or audit basis. All requests for substitution, other than those listed under the Engineering Physics Program, must be approved by the Departmental Representative in advance.

req_list.name: Mechanical Engineering
req_list.explanation: Mechanical Engineering. This program deals with the analysis and design of machines, their motion, power sources, and control. The curriculum is based on dynamics, thermodynamics, and the study of the structure and behavior of fluid and solid materials; it is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET.

req_list.name: Required
req_list.explanation: MAE 305/MAT 301 required for both Mechanical and Aerospace Engineers.

req_list.name: Mathematics Elective
course_list: ORF 363/COS 323: Computing and Optimization for the Physical and Social Sciences
COS 302: Mathematics for Numerical Computing and Machine Learning

req_list.name: Engineering Science Courses
req_list.explanation: In the Mechanical Program five courses are required from Dynamics and Control, Fluid Mechanics and Thermal Sciences, and Materials and Structures.

req_list.name: Dynamics and Control
req_list.explanation: MAE 433 required for Mechanical and Aerospace Engineers.

req_list.name: Fluid Mechanics and Thermal Sciences
req_list.explanation:
MAE 335 or 336 or 423 required for Mechanical Engineers.

Note: CBE 341 is an acceptable substitute for MAE 423 for Mechanical Engineers.
course_list: CBE 341: Mass, Momentum, and Energy Transport

req_list.name: Materials
req_list.explanation:
MAE 324 or MSE 301 required for Mechanical and Aerospace Engineers

Note: CEE 362 or CEE 364 may be considered as substitutes for the materials requirement. Requires the approval of the Department Representative.
course_list: MAE 324: Structure and Properties of Materials
CEE 362: Structural Dynamics and Earthquake Engineering

req_list.name: Structures
req_list.explanation: CEE 312 or 361 required for Mechanical and Aerospace Engineers.
course_list: CEE 361/MAE 325: Structural Analysis and Intro to Finite Element Methods

req_list.name: Engineering Design Courses
req_list.explanation: There are three design requirements in each program. Two are satisfied by completing courses appropriate to the program. The third is satisfied by completing Senior Independent Work, Senior Thesis, or Senior Project.

req_list.name: Required
req_list.explanation: MAE 321 required for Mechanical Engineers and Aerospace Engineers

req_list.name: Concentration Requirement
req_list.explanation:
MAE 322 or MAE 412 required for Mechanical Engineers

Note: CEE 477 is an acceptable substitute only for Mechanical Engineers who are pursuing the Sustainable Energy Certificate Program
course_list: MAE 412: Microprocessors for Measurement and Control
CEE 477: Engineering Design for Sustainable Development

req_list.name: Aerospace Engineering
req_list.explanation: Aerospace Engineering. This program deals with the analysis and design of aerospace vehicles. The curriculum is based on the applications of principles from dynamics, control, thermodynamics, fluid mechanics and solid mechanics; it is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET.

req_list.name: Applications of Mathematics
req_list.explanation: MAE 305/MAT 301 required for both Mechanical and Aerospace Engineers.

req_list.name: Engineering Science Courses
req_list.explanation: In the Aerospace Program six courses are required from Sections Dynamics and Control, Fluid Mechanics and Thermal Sciences, and Materials and Structures.

req_list.name: Dynamics and Control
req_list.explanation: MAE 433 required for Mechanical and Aerospace Engineers. MAE 331 or 341 required for Aerospace Engineers.

req_list.name: Fluid Mechanics and Thermal Sciences
req_list.explanation: MAE 335 required for Aerospace Engineers. MAE 427 or 426 required for Aerospace Engineers (may be used as additional engineering science elective (technical elective) in the Mechanical Program.

req_list.name: Materials
req_list.explanation:
MAE 324 or MSE 301 required for Mechanical and Aerospace Engineers

Note: CEE 362 or CEE 364 may be considered as substitutes for the materials requirement. Requires the approval of the Department Representative.
course_list: MAE 324: Structure and Properties of Materials
CEE 362: Structural Dynamics and Earthquake Engineering

req_list.name: Structures
req_list.explanation: MAE 323 or CEE 312 or CEE 361 required for Mechanical and Aerospace Engineers.
course_list: CEE 361/MAE 325: Structural Analysis and Intro to Finite Element Methods

req_list.name: Engineering Design Courses
req_list.explanation: There are three design requirements in each program. Two are satisfied by completing courses appropriate to the program. The third is satisfied by completing Senior Independent Work, Senior Thesis, or Senior Project.

req_list.name: Required
req_list.explanation: MAE 321 required for Mechanical Engineers and Aerospace Engineers

req_list.name: Concentration Requirement
req_list.explanation: MAE 332 or MAE 342 required for Aerospace Engineers

req_list.name: Senior Independent Work
req_list.explanation: Senior Independent Work is the culminating experience for the mechanical and aerospace engineering programs. All seniors are required to participate in a research or engineering project. All projects must include elements of engineering design (engineering design is the process of devising a system, component, or process to meet desired needs). The following courses satisfy this requirement: MAE 439 Senior Independent Work (one semester, fall); MAE 440 Senior Independent Work (one semester, spring); MAE 442 Senior Thesis (yearlong); MAE 444 Senior Project (year-long). Students are strongly encouraged to select the year-long project or thesis option. Senior projects are intended for teams or groups while senior thesis is intended for individuals. For senior project or thesis, work begins in the fall but enrollment is only in spring term when a double grade is awarded. Please note: If a student has selected to participate in a year-long project or thesis and is enrolled in only three courses during the fall semester, it is required that they will enroll in Senior Project or Thesis during the spring semester. For these students, it will NOT be possible to drop-down to a one-semester course of Independent Work without incurring a failure for Independent Work in the fall term. In Spring term you must enroll in three courses plus senior thesis or senior project (senior thesis and senior project count as two courses). Therefore your senior year course load will be 3 in fall and 5 in spring as opposed to 4 in fall and 4 in spring. There are NO exceptions to this rule even if your total number of courses will exceed 36.
course_list: MAE 439: Senior Independent Work (one semester, fall)
MAE 440: Senior Independent Work (one semester, spring)
